raw_text: [Fass, 1988, Hinkelman, 1989, Martin, 1990, Pustejovsky, 1991, Zernik, 1987] A careful analysis of these disparate fforts reveals that a common approach to the semantic interpretation of non-literal language may be emerging
The work of Pustejovsky [Pustejovsky, 1991] is related in its attempt o reduce the size and complexity of individual lexical entries

citing_paper_authors: Alex, Judea | Vivi, Nastase | Katja, Markert | Michael, Strube
raw_text: Our view of relations in a concept network being the interpretations of metonymies is strongly reminiscent of older work in metonymy resolution such as Hobbs et al1993), Fass (1991), Markert and Hahn (2002) or the use of a generative lexicon and its relations in Pustejovsky (1991), which also are unsupervised
clean_text: Our view of relations in a concept network being the interpretations of metonymies is strongly reminiscent of older work in metonymy resolution such as Hobbs et al1993), Fass (1991), Markert and Hahn (2002) or the use of a generative lexicon and its relations in Pustejovsky (1991), which also are unsupervised.

raw_text: The term quale (plural :qualia) is borrowed from Pustejovsky (1991)
clean_text: The term quale (plural :qualia) is borrowed from Pustejovsky (1991).

citing_paper_authors: Rajen, Subba | Barbara Di, Eugenio | Su Nam, Kim
raw_text: To provide semantics for nouns, we use CoreLex (Buitelaar, 1998), in turn based on the generative lexicon (Pustejovsky, 1991)
clean_text: To provide semantics for nouns, we use CoreLex (Buitelaar, 1998), in turn based on the generative lexicon (Pustejovsky, 1991).

raw_text: CoreLex is based on a different theory than Levin? s (that of the generative lexicon (Pustejovsky, 1991)), but does provide a compatible decompositional meaning representation for nouns
clean_text: CoreLex is based on a different theory than Levin's (that of the generative lexicon (Pustejovsky, 1991)), but does provide a compatible decompositional meaning representation for nouns.

raw_text: There are several alternative approaches that might eventually liberate us from this limitation on the usability of MT systems: Unification-based grammar formalisms and lexical-semantics formalisms (see LFG (Kaplan and Bresnan, 1982), HPSG (Pollard and Sag, 1987), and Generative Lexicon (Pustejovsky, 1991), for example) have been proposed to facilitate computationally precise description of natural language syntax and semantics
clean_text: Generative Lexicon (Pustejovsky, 1991), for example have been proposed to facilitate computationally precise description of natural language syntax and semantics.

raw_text: The idea that noun meaning involves ewmt-based escription has been particularly emphasized by J. Pustejovsky (1991)
clean_text: The idea that noun meaning involves event-based description has been particularly emphasized by J. Pustejovsky (1991).

raw_text: This semantic framework demonstrates that the association between nominal constituents and underlying predicative relation in root compounds is not arbitrary: it involves conceptual mechanisms that are triggered in other linguistic phenomena such as type coercion (Pustejovsky, 1991), anaphora (Fradin, 1984) or adjectival constructions (Bouillon and Viegas, 1993)
clean_text: This semantic framework demonstrates that the association between nominal constituents and underlying predicative relation in root compounds is not arbitrary: it involves conceptual mechanisms that are triggered in other linguistic phenomena such as type coercion (Pustejovsky, 1991), anaphora (Fradin, 1984) or adjectival constructions (Bouillon and Viegas, 1993).

raw_text: Such com -pounds illustrate the notion of co-compositionality (Pustejovsky 1991)
clean_text: Such compounds illustrate the notion of co-compositionality (Pustejovsky 1991).

raw_text: Pustejovsky (1991) refers to this kind of relation as co specification :i.e. like verb can select for its argument type, an argument also can select its associated predicates
clean_text: Pustejovsky (1991) refers to this kind of relation as co specification i.e. like verb can select for its argument type, an argument also can select its associated predicates.

raw_text: The associated predicate information is included in the qualia structure of a lexical item (Pustejovsky, 1991)
clean_text: The associated predicate information is included in the qualia structure of a lexical item (Pustejovsky, 1991).

raw_text: I declare that Korean common nouns have both the RESTR (ICTION) for normal semantics and the QUALIA-ST (RUCTURE), which in turn has the AGENTIVE and TELIC attributes, adopting the basic idea from Pustejovsky (1991) and adapting the feature structure from Copestake (1993)
clean_text: I declare that Korean common nouns have both the RESTR (ICTION) for normal semantics and the QUALIA-ST (RUCTURE), which in turn has the AGENTIVE and TELIC attributes, adopting the basic idea from Pustejovsky (1991).

raw_text: The VPs with the verbs start or finish (see Pustejovsky, 1991) can also be accounted for using the qualia structure :e.g. ,pap-ulsicakhata/kkuthnayta &apos ;start/ finish (cooking/*eating) the rice ' ,khephi-lulsicakhata/kkuthnayta &apos ;start/ finish (brewing/*drinking) the coffee ' ,khemphuthe-lulsicakhata/kkuthnayta &apos ;start/ finish (*building/using) the computer ' and *mwul-ulsicakhata/kkuthnayta
clean_text: The VPs with the verbs start or finish (see Pustejovsky, 1991) can also be accounted for using the qualia structure.

raw_text: The vast space between these two extremes can still be explained in terms of compositional principles with mechanisms from GLT such as type coercion and sub selection (Pustejovsky, 1991, 1993), as we shall see below
clean_text: The vast space between these two extremes can still be explained in terms of compositional principles with mechanisms from GLT such as type coercion and sub selection (Pustejovsky, 1991, 1993).

raw_text: The Generative Lexicon Theory (GLT) (Pustejovsky, 1991, 1994c) can be said to take advantage of both linguistic and conceptual approaches, providing a framework which arose from the integration of linguistic studies and of techniques found in AI
clean_text: The Generative Lexicon Theory (GLT) (Pustejovsky, 1991, 1994c) can be said to take advantage of both linguistic and conceptual approaches, providing a framework which arose from the integration of linguistic studies and of techniques found in AI.

raw_text: The basic sense originates derived usages, which are more or less constrained and limited, via metonymy, metaphor, slight sense-shiftings or co-composition (Pustejovsky, 1991, 1995)
clean_text: The basic sense originates derived usages, which are more or less constrained and limited, via metonymy, metaphor, slight sense-shiftings or co-composition (Pustejovsky, 1991, 1995).

raw_text: Finally, SEMANTIC COLLOCATIONS like long book derive their particular meaning from the recovery in context of parameters for events and other entities (Pustejovsky, 1991)
clean_text: Finally, SEMANTIC COLLOCATIONS like long book derive their particular meaning from the recovery in context of parameters for events and other entities (Pustejovsky, 1991).

raw_text: We are investigating the use of principles of the Generative Lexicon (Pustejovsky 1991) for that purpose
clean_text: We are investigating the use of principles of the Generative Lexicon (Pustejovsky 1991) for that purpose.

raw_text: Qualia structures have been originally introduced by (Pustejovsky, 1991) and are used for a variety of purposes in natural language processing (NLP), such as for the analysis of compounds (Johnston and Busa, 1996) as well as co-composition and coercion (Pustejovsky, 1991), but also for bridging reference resolution (Bos et al, 1995)
clean_text: Qualia structures have been originally introduced by (Pustejovsky, 1991) and are used for a variety of purposes in natural language processing (NLP).
